summary: The appellant Shyam Babu has moved the Supreme Court against the order of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad setting aside the acquittal of the accused in a murder case of 1978. On 21.12.1978, Ujagar Singh, Jaswant Singh, Gaya Prasad, Pahunchi Lal, Lalta Prasad and Prayag Singh were on their way home from work when they came under the attack of 7 accused persons, viz., Shyam Babu, Babu Ram, Tej Ram, Mahipal Singh, Indal and Bhabhooti. 6) We are of the considered view that the decision of the High Court to acquit all the accused in the Pahunchi Lal murder case is perverse and unreasonable resulting in miscarriage of justice.

summary: The following is a verbatim transcript of the judgement of the Supreme Court of India in the case of P.A.Mohammed Riyas vs M.K.Raghavan & Ors. The Election Appeal against the decision of the High Court dismissing the Election Petition filed by the Appellant against the Respondent No.1 for allegedly making false statements in the publications of the Press Trust of India, the Hindu and the Times of India. The Supreme Court has held that an affidavit in Form 25 is not an integral part of an Election Petition, as has been the case in the following cases: (i) Bhimrao Ambedkar Vs. Venugopal next urged that it had been contended on behalf of the Respondent No.1 that the Election Petitioner/Appellant had filed only one affidavit under Order VI Rule 15(4) of the CPC and had not filed a separate and second affidavit in Form 25, as provided under Section 94A of the Conduct of Election Rules, 1961, which is also required to be filed under the proviso to Section 83(1) of the Act in support of an allegation of a corrupt practice.

summary: Justice Swatanter Kumar and Justice Aftab Alam are judges of the Supreme Court of India. This is an appeal against the order of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh suspending the mining operations of Obulapuram Mining Company (OMC) and other companies, on the basis of the findings of a High Level Committee, headed by the Principal Chief Conservator of Forests, Hyderabad and the Report of the CEC submitted to this Court in I. The petitioner prayed that the Central Electricity Commission (CEC) be directed to take immediate steps to stop the illegal mining and related activities in the forest areas of the State of Andhra Pradesh and the State of Karnataka.

summary: The appellant has moved this court against the order of the Gujarat High Court cancelling the offer of appointment as Director, Computer Department in the Hemchandracharya North Gujarat University. The appellant was offered the post of Director, All India Council for the Technical Education (AICTE) by the Council in a letter dated 15th February, 2010. The Gujarat High Court has ruled that a person getting higher pay cannot be deputed against a lower scale of pay and the appellant has no right to claim his entitlement to the post of Director, AICTE.

summary: Appeal by special leave. Counsel submitted that Section 53 of the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, 1988 (the Code) was amended in 2005 and, as a result, it is not applicable to the present case. Counsel submitted that the power of a Magistrate to compel a person to give voice sample is not limited to the provisions of the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act.

summary: The Uttarakhand High Court has ruled that over-payment of amount due to wrong fixation of 5th and 6th pay scale of teachers/principals based on the 5th Pay Commission could be recovered from the recipients who are serving as teachers. The Uttarakhand High Court has quashed an inter-departmental communication dated 24.10.2009 and a letter dated 18.11.2009 issued by the District Education Officer to the Manager/Principal of few Sanskrit Colleges in Hardwar where excess payments were made due to wrong fixation of pay. The appellants have challenged an order of the District Education Officer, Haridwar, which directed the appellants to retain the excess salary paid to them on the basis of irregular/wrong pay fixation.

summary: The Supreme Court of India in a landmark case has ruled that a person who dies in a motor accident can be entitled to compensation even if the death was caused by the negligence of the driver of the vehicle. In the case of minors, illiterate claimants and widows, the Tribunal should ordinarily invest the amount of compensation in long term fixed deposit. The Supreme Court has held that the Motor Accidents Tribunals have no power to release the entire amount of compensation to the claimant even if it is required by him.

summary: The Kerala High Court has ruled that the Commissioner of Income Tax, Thrissur, did not have the power to impose penalty on Catholic Syrian Bank Ltd. This is an appeal against an order of the Commissioner of Income Tax (Appeals) dated 7th April, 2006, in the case of Catholic Syrian Bank Ltd. Section 36(1)(viia) and 36(2)(v) of the Income Tax Act provide that "Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act, any person who makes provision for bad and doubtful debts normally is not an allowable deduction and what is allowable under main clause is bad debt actually written off."

summary: The Kerala High Court has granted leave to an insurance company to appeal against an order of the Commissioner for Workmen’s Compensation, Kerala, directing it to pay 12% simple interest at the rate of 12% per annum from the date of an accident. In Mubasir Ahmad the Court held that “interest due to default in payment of compensation is not payable from the date of award of compensation”. Nasir that the rate of interest provided under sub-section (3) of section 4-A would apply only in case the “finding of fact as envisaged therein” is arrived at by the Commissioner, it must respectfully be stated, seems to result from the mixing up of ‘interest due to default in payment of compensation’ and ‘penalty for an unjustified delay in payment of compensation’ and is based on a misreading of the sub-section (3) of section 4-A. In Mubasir Ahmed, the Supreme Court held that an employer who fails to pay compensation to a workman within a reasonable time is not liable to pay interest.

summary: The High Court of Tamil Nadu has granted leave to one Sengoda Gounder, who is not a party to the Special Leave Petition, essentially, for the specific performance of a registered agreement dated 22-03-1995, of sale of the suit scheduled land admeasuring approximately Acs.2-00 and delivery of possession of the same; in the alternative, it was prayed that the defendant be directed to refund the amount of Rs.15,125/- with interest, etc. In the above-mentioned case, the plaintiffs had filed three representations of the plaint in the District Court, Erode, seeking quashing of the decision of the Trial Court in I.A.No.76 of 2004 to condone the delay of 1328 days in the first of the abovementioned three representations of the plaint. In this case, the High Court held that the 2nd defendant has no locus standi to challenge the decision of the Trial Court to condone the delay in representation of the plaint.

summary: Ramesh Ahluwalia vs State Of Punjab & Ors on 13 September, 2012 The Punjab and Haryana High Court has dismissed a writ petition challenging the order of the Disciplinary Committee of a private school in Chandigarh, which had imposed a fine of 50,000 on an employee for bringing the school into disrepute. summary: Appeal by the State of Madhya Pradesh against the judgment and order of the High Court quashing the applications for appointment on the post of Project Director of Child Labour Elimination and Rehabilitation Society. Sandhya Tomar and Anr had joined the Panchayat & Rural Development Society in the State of Orissa on 15.0.2003, but she was not appointed following the procedure mandatorily required by law, as several other eligible candidates have been deprived of their right to be considered for the post. The Supreme Court has set aside an order of the Single Judge of the Division Bench of the Allahabad High Court, which had dismissed an appeal of a former employee of the Indian Council of Medical Research, who had challenged an advertisement dated 16.5.2005, issued by the Society, inviting applications for the post of Project Director.

summary: The Supreme Court has issued notice to the State of Assam on a writ petition challenging the selection made by the Assam Public Service Commission (for short, ‘he Commission’) for 116 posts of Assam Civil Service Class-I (Junior Grade), Assam Police Service (Junior Grade), Labour Officer, Assistant Registrar of Cooperative Societies, Inspector of Taxes and Inspector of Excise. A Division Bench of the Assam High Court has held that the actions of the Public Service Commission did not result in usurpation of the quota earmarked for the reserved category in the Assam Civil Service. In two separate cases, the Supreme Court of India considered the constitutional validity of reservation of socially and educationally backward classes under Article 16(4) of the Constitution of India.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that the methodology adopted by Bhubaneswar Development Authority (BDA) in allotment of 45 plots situated within the city of Orissa to the citizens of Orissa on "First Come First Served" basis, can be said to be just, proper legally tenable method. Here is the appeal filed by the Bhubaneswar Development Authority (BDA) against the order of the Orissa High Court, which had allowed the Writ Petitions filed by Adikanda Biswal & Ors against the cancellation of the process of allotment of developed plots to those applicants who may fulfill other criteria as envisaged under the general conditions fixed by the BDA under its Scheme. Learned senior counsel submitted that the High Court was justified in quashing the decision taken by the authority in the absence of any material to show that the decision taken for allotment of plots following the "First Come First Served" basis was vitiated by any extraneous or irrelevant considerations.

summary: The Supreme Court has granted leave to a retired judge of the High Court of Uttar Pradesh to continue as Chairperson of the Electricity Regulatory Commission. A writ petition has been filed in the High Court of Andhra Pradesh against the appointment of Rajesh Awasthi as Chairperson of the Andhra Pradesh Electricity Commission, alleging that the Selection Committee of the Commission had failed to follow the provisions of sub-section (5) of Section 85 of the Andhra Pradesh Electricity Act. The appellant has been appointed as the Chairperson of the State Commission for Urban Development in the state of U.P.

summary: The appellant, Mohammed Ajmal Mohammad Kasab @ Abu Mujahid (hereinafter referred to as ‘Kasab’), who is a Pakistani national, has earned for himself five death penalties and an equal number of life sentences in prison for committing multiple crimes of a horrendous kind in this country. summary: The following is the text of the judgement delivered by the Supreme Court of India in the case of New India Assurance Co. The dependants of Nanag Ram, a bread winner, who died in a road accident in Jaipur, Rajasthan, in 1992, had filed a petition in the Rajasthan High Court for award of compensation to the tune of Rs.24 by alleging that their bread winner had died due to rash and negligent driving of a truck by Shri Raghu Nath. The appellant, New India Assurance Co., filed a special leave petition in the Kerala High Court against the order of the Single Judge of the High Court, which held that the deceased employee of the appellant was entitled to a bonus of 20 per cent of his salary.

summary: Three separate appeals have been heard by the Supreme Court of India on the question of whether a person who has demitted office as a Member of the Customs Excise and Service Taxppellate Tribunal is entitled to appear before the CESTAT. The appellants were appointed as members of the Appellate Tribunal constituted under the Customs, Excise and Service Tax Act, 2001 and they were debarred from appearing before the Tribunal or its Benches anywhere in India in view of Section 129(6) of the Customs Act. The Appellate Tribunal is an independent body set up by the government of India to hear appeals against decisions of the High Court and the Supreme Court.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that an employer can take disciplinary action against an employee in regard to acts purported to have been done by him in his previous employment in an affiliated society. The Division Bench of the Calcutta High Court, while disposing of the appeal of the State Bank of West Bengal against the order of the Disciplinary Authority of the Bank, held that the Respondent No.1 had not been prejudiced in any way on account of non-supply of the report of the Enquiry Officer or in the absence of a second show-cause notice, as was earlier envisaged under Article 311(2) of the Constitution prior to its amendment by the 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976. Tarun Kumar Ray, learned senior advocate appearing for the Appellant-Bank, urged that the Respondent No.1 had not been prejudiced in any way on account of non-supply of the report of the Enquiry Officer or in the absence of a second show-cause notice, as was earlier envisaged under Article 311(2) of the Constitution prior to its amendment by the 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976. summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that a convicted rapist who was not represented in the Orissa High Court is entitled to legal representation in the High Court. Section 12 of the Legal Services Authorities Act provides for the provision of legal services to an eligible person at all stages of the proceedings, trial as well as appellate. In a recent case, the Supreme Court of India held that a person accused of an offence or convicted of an offence should be entitled to free legal aid.

summary: The Supreme Court of Madhya Pradesh has issued notice to the Municipal Council of Sendhwa and Tejas Construction & Infras on an appeal filed by Tejas Construction & Infras against an order of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh which dismissed a writ petition challenging the allotment of project work involving design, construction and commissioning of a single integrated water supply at Sendhwa. The appellant has challenged the allotment of work to respondent No.2 on the ground that respondent No.2 had not filed the requisite certified balance-sheets for five years immediately preceding the issue of tender notice and that respondent No.2 did not have the requisite experience of executing a single integrated water supply scheme of the required value. The Supreme Court of India has held that the Writ Court cannot be justified in interfering with commercial transactions in which the State is one of the parties to the same except where there is substantial public interest involved and in cases where the transaction is mala fide.

summary: This case has been listed for hearing on 4 December, 2012 by the Supreme Court of India. Learned senior counsel brought to our notice the Gujarat Agricultural Lands Ceiling (Amendment) Act, 1972 (being Gujarat Act No.2 of 1974) (hereinafter called the Amendment Act, 1974) wherein, inter alia, it sought to remove doubts relating to ‘Bid lands’ of former Princes, as well as, Girasdars and Barkhalidars in the Saurashtra area which were duly covered under the definition of ‘land’ and submitted that it was State Of Gujarat & Anr vs Manoharsinhji Pradyumansinhji Jadeja on 4 December, 2012 Indian Kanoon - http://indiankanoon.org/doc/110454153/ The learned senior counsel submitted that the respondent was not entitled to enjoy the benefit of the ceiling limit prescribed under Section 6 of Act of 1960 as the said ceiling limit was not applicable to the ‘Bid lands’ of the respondent and, therefore, the said ceiling limit was not applicable to the ‘Bid lands’ of the respondent.

summary: Appeal from the Allahabad High Court against the ruling of the Munsif, Karwi (Banda) that the writ petition filed by the appellant was not maintainable in terms of Order XXIII Rule 3-A of the Code of Civil Procedure. The Supreme Court has held that a suit for setting aside a compromise decree can only be challenged before the same court that recorded the comprise and a fresh suit for setting aside a compromise decree is expressly barred under Order XXIII Rule 3-A. summary: The Supreme Court of India has reserved its verdict on an appeal by a woman against a lower court's order convicting her of rape. Two appeals were filed against an order of the Bombay High Court quashing a criminal proceeding under Sections 138 and 141 of the Companies Act, 1956. In a landmark case, the Supreme Court has ruled that it would be unconstitutional to hold a company, the prime offender, liable for commission of an offence although it does not get an opportunity to defend itself.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has issued a series of directions on the issue of compensation awarded to victims of road accidents. The Supreme Court has ruled in the case ofohan Soni vs Ram Avtar Tomar & Ors that "the Tribunal was in error in pegging down the disability of the appellant to 50% with reference to Schedule 1 of the Workmen's Compensation Act, 1923." In K. Janardhan, the Supreme Court of India held that the Commissioner of Workmen's Compensation did not have the jurisdiction to award compensation to a man who had suffered a permanent disability as a result of an accident.

summary: Equivalent citations: 2012 AIR SCW 930, 2012 (2) SCC 648, 2012 CRI. The appellant Anthony Pareira was found guilty of causing grievous injury to seven people who were sleeping on footpath by driving his car in a rash and negligent manner and thereby committed an offence punishable under Section 304A IPC and Section 337 IPC. summary: The Supreme Court of India has taken up the issue of suo motu entertained and taken cognizance of a complaint directly by the police in a Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act case. The appellants have challenged the conviction and sentence passed by the Court of Session of Madhya Pradesh under Section 193 of the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, 2000. It is pertinent to mention here that the Supreme Court of India has held that the Special Judge under the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1988 has no jurisdiction or authority to take cognizance of a complaint filed before it and issue process after taking cognizance without the case being committed to it for trial by the Magistrate.

summary: The Supreme Court has upheld the conviction and sentence of Surinder Kumar for driving his wife to suicide. Except my husband, my mother-in-law, sister-in-law, brother-in-law or other members of my in laws had not made any demands of dowry and only my husband Surinder Kumar used to make the demands of dowry and I have set myself on fire after pouring kerosene oil being fed up from the demands of dowry made by my husband. summary: The Supreme Court of India has disposed off two separate appeals by Sahara India Real Estate Corporation and Sahara Housing Investment Corporation Limited against the orders of the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) and the Bombay High Court, respectively. Sahara India Real Estate Corporation (formerly Sahara India 'C' Junxion Limited) has filed an Information Memorandum with the Registrar of Companies (RoC) of the state of Uttar Pradesh in connection with a private placement of shares and debentures (OFCDs) by Sahara India Real Estate Corporation (formerly Sahara India 'C' Junxion Limited). On 25.4.2008, SIRECL had issued an issue of eighty one million rupees (Rs.15,530/-) of Nirmaan and Real Estate Bonds in the name of Sahara India Real Estate Corporation Limited (SIRCEL) as an open ended scheme and collected an amount of Rs.19400,86,64,200 (Seventeen thousand four hundred crores, six lacs, sixty four thousand and two hundred only) from 25.4.2008 to 13.4.2011.

summary: Appeal by Rev. Mother Marykutty against the judgment of the High Court of Kerala passed in Criminal Appeal No.1707/2007. The appellant has moved this Court challenging the order of the Kerala High Court quashing her petition challenging the acquittal of her by the trial Court on the ground that she was not entitled for the acquittal. The Court of Appeal for Kerala has held that the High Court did not discharge its onerous responsibility of considering the material evidence available on record which were brought to its notice and for the reasons best known, the High Court blatantly declined to examine those materials by simply stating that the same was not warranted.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that soft serve, commonly known as McDonalds, is classifiable under heading 21.05 of the Central Excise and Tariff Act, 1985. The Commissioner of Central Excise (Appeals) issued three show cause notices to the assessee, Shree Baidyanath Ayurved Bhavan Limited (SConnaught Plaza Rest.), New Delhi, for allegedly selling soft serve mix as ice-cream. The learned counsel appearing for the assessee submitted that ‘soft serve’ cannot be classified as “ice-cream”.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that a person illegally dispossessed of immovable property should be entitled to possession of the property on the relevant date. The defendant filed a suit against Jagdish & others for an order of injunction restraining Jagdish & others from raising any construction on the suit land and from transferring/ alienating the same. In the written statement filed, it was averred that on 28.9.1978, Jagdish & others had entered into an agreement with Murari Lal for sale of his half share of the suit land which, once again, he had admitted the possession of the defendant over the entire land.

summary: The Patna High Court has granted leave to the Registrar General, Patna High Court, to appeal against the judgment and order rendered by a Division Bench of the High Court in the writ petition filed by respondent no.1. summary: Aggrieved parties have been granted leave to appeal to the Supreme Court. Section 31(7)(b) of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1997 provides as under: " (a) A sum directed to be paid by an arbitral award shall, unless the award otherwise directs, carry interest at the rate of eighteen per centum per annum from the date of award. summary: The writ petitions challenging the constitutional validity of the amendment of the Election Symbols (Reservation and Allotment Order, 1968) and the Election Commission of India's (ECI) decision not to grant recognition to the Dravida Murpokku Dravida Kazhagam (DMK) as a State party in the Tamil Nadu State are listed for final hearing on 18 April, 2012. The Election Commission of India has been involved in a series of discussions with political parties and other interested parties on the issue of election symbols. Clause 15 of the Election Symbols Order, 1968, as a whole, could not be challenged as a valid ground for assailing the said clause.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has upheld the conviction and sentence imposed on the appellant for the offence under Sections 302 and 201 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC). On the complaint of P.W.2 that Om Prakash, a resident of Gharsana in Jaisalmer district of Rajasthan, had gone missing from his house on the morning of 5 October, 1997 and his body had not been found as yet, the appellant Shanti Devi, a resident of Gharsana in Jaisalmer district of Rajasthan, gave an extra-judicial confession to the police that she had killed Om Prakash and buried his body near her house. Learned counsel for the appellant submitted that the evidence gathered by the Courts below was not sufficient to establish the guilt of the appellant on the charge of murder.

summary: Appeal by Mangani Lal Mandal against the judgment of the Patna High Court which set aside his election to the 15th Lok Sabha on the ground that he had two wives and dependent children born out of wedlock. The appellant has filed an appeal against the order of the High Court declaring the election of the petitioner as void on the ground that he had not complied with the provisions of the Constitution or the 1951 Act or any rules or orders made thereunder. summary: Appeal by the State of Haryana and the Land Acquisition Collector, Urban Estate, Panchkula against the judgment and order of the Panchkula High Court dated April 1, 2003. The appellants filed an application before the High Court of Punjab for grant of benefits of the amended provisions of the Land Acquisition Act to them. The High Court allowed the application made by the respondents for grant of benefits of the amended provisions on April 28, 1989 and granted benefits of the amended provisions of Sections 23(1-A) and 23(2) of the LA Act to them. The Punjab and Haryana High Court has ruled that it has no jurisdiction to award enhanced solatium and interest to expropriated owners under the Punjab Land Acquisition Act (LA).

summary: A bench of Justice Altamas Kabir of the Delhi High Court has issued notice to a retired army officer and his wife on a special leave petition challenging an eviction order passed by a Magistrate under the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005. The learned Judge held that a petition under the provisions of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence (PWD) Act, 2005, is maintainable even if the acts of domestic violence had been committed prior to the coming into force of the said Act, notwithstanding the fact that in the past she had lived together with her husband in a shared household, but was no more living with him, at the time when the Act came into force. The Supreme Court has ruled that a woman who is a victim of domestic violence should be provided with a right of residence where she is residing, by way of relief under Section 19 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has issued the following directions in the case of Wokadine Surgical USP and Povidone Iodine Cleansing Solution USP. The assessee had filed a reply to the show cause notices issued by the adjudicating authority, who by his order dated 15.11.2001 had directed the assessee to pay the difference in duty and also the penalty. The appellants have moved this Court against the order of the Central Board of Excise and Customs (CBEC) and the decision of the Central Board of Indirect Taxes and Customs (CBIC) Tribunal in the matter of Povidone Iodine Solution or its patent and proprietary equivalent Wokadine surgical scrub.

summary: Convicted in a 2002 double murder case, Sahadevan and Anr appeal against conviction and sentence passed by the High Court of Tamil Nadu. The appellants have challenged the conviction of them under Section 120B IPC and Section 302 IPC on the ground that the extra-judicial confession made by them was neither reliable nor recorded in accordance with law. The Court of Appeal, Kabeernagar Division, Kabeernagar, Tamil Nadu, while disposing of the appeal of Kabeernagar, Division, Kabeernagar, Tamil Nadu, against the conviction of the accused in the Kabeernagar rape case, held that the trial court was correct in convicting the accused on the basis of circumstantial evidence.

summary: The appellant- Attarsingh Barakya Pawara has challenged the conviction and sentence passed by the High Court of Judicature at Bombay for the offence of murder under the Indian Penal Code (I.P.C.). The learned Sessions Judge on a scrutiny of the evidence and other materials on record rejected the defence story set up on behalf of the appellant as the evidence is missing that the accused-appellant was subjecting his wife to cruelty by abusing and assaulting her from time to time. The appellant was convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment by the sessions court under Section 302 I.P.C. as also the High Court which concurrently upheld the conviction of the appellant under Section 302 I.P.C., the counsel for the appellant first of all attempted to demolish the case of the prosecution in its entirety by submitting that the conviction and sentence imposed on the appellant was not fit to be sustained on the testimony of the daughter Mangibai as she had not supported the prosecution version totally due to which she had been declared hostile.

summary: This article is copyrighted. The meaning of damages in personal injury cases is given as follows: - “The award of damages in personal injury cases seeks to achieve restitutio in integrum, for while the traditional pleading distinction between ‘special’ and ‘general’ damages by no means corresponds to the traditional pleading distinction between ‘pecuniary’ losses and out-of- pocket expenses, the latter comprises not only non-pecuniary losses but also prospective loss of earnings and other future pecuniary damage. It is noteworthy to state that the concept of “just compensation”, as its nomenclature, denotes equitability, fairness and reasonableness, if it exceeds; it is termed as unfair, unreasonable, unequitable, not just.

summary: A short but interesting question of law arises in these Special Leave Petitions, as to whether appointments can be made in Government service beyond the number of vacancies advertised. A Division Bench of the Gauhati High Court has dismissed two Writ Petitions challenging the decision of the Single Judge of the Gauhati High Court to quash the selection of 212 candidates and appointment of 137 candidates for the posts of Deputy Commissioner of Gauhati. An extract from the judgement of the Supreme Court of India in the case of Tamil Nadu Public Service Commission against the Pondicherry Public Service Commission has been released.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has issued notice to the Government of Rajasthan, the Rajasthan University of Health Science and Ors, and the Rajasthan Medical College and Hospital, Udaipur, on appeals by Rajan Purohit and Geetanjali Ors against the Rajasthan High Court's order of 03.09.2009 suspending admission to Rajanjali Medical College and Hospital. The Geetanjali Foundation has set up a private medical and dental college at Bharatpur in the state of Rajasthan with an annual intake of 150 students for the academic year 2008-2009. The Rajasthan High Court has ruled that the admissions made by the Jaipur State College for the academic year 2008-2009 against 85% of the seats were illegal and directed that the writ petitioners will be given admission as per their merit position in the waiting list and the process be completed before the commencement of the RPM-2009.

summary: Appeal by Premji Nathu against the judgment of the Gujarat High Court in favour of the State of Gujarat. The appellant and other landowners have been granted leave to appeal against the judgment of the Reference Court and the judgment of the Single Judge of the High Court, which held that the applications filed by the appellant and other land owners were barred by time.
